snippet: A measure making it a crime to call someone a Nazi battles the trivialization of an atrocity, but not everyone agrees that this is the way to proceed.
abstract: Israel's Parliament gives preliminary approval to measure that would make it a crime to call someone a Nazi, or any other slur associated with Third Reich; backers say proposed law is response to rising tide of anti-Semitism, but critics believe it is dangerous infringement on free speech and an overreach impossible to enforce.

byline.contributor: Hannah Olivennes and Bernadette Murphy contributed research from Paris, and Lucy Jordan from Brasília.

lead_paragraph: A measure making it a crime to call someone a Nazi battles the trivialization of an atrocity, but not everyone agrees that this is the way to proceed.

headline.main: Israel’s Efforts to Limit Use of Holocaust Terms Raise Free-Speech Questions
headline.print_headline: Israel’s Efforts to Limit Use of Holocaust Terms Raise Free-Speech Questions
